So attack vectors are basically code paths that allow a malicious user,
such as a hacker or somebody, a user that sends unintentional code
to your software that either gives them unauthorized access.
And these can, in traditional software,
you have command line arguments where you can pass,
well, you can pass like some hacker can pass a carefully crafted
code, such as a shell code with some buffer overflow exploits
and basically give them access to that machine.
Environment variables as well and URL parameters,
which is common in web application hacking,
where you can basically have a hacker send SQL injection commands
into your application by basically sending a carefully crafted post data
or URL parameter.
And also data storage, which falls in the same concept
as the previous post of URL parameters.
In this case, somebody has access to the database
and your application reads some data from that data
and causes your application to behave in a way that you were not expecting to.
And in the case of solidity and Ethereum contracts,
these are function parameters and third party contracts
that can access your contracts.
